images.alt:
« Vous savez, Vladimir Poutine m’a dit un truc, l’une des choses les plus intéressantes », a déclaré Donald Trump au présentateur Sean Hannity de Fox News.

« Il m’a dit : “Votre élection a été truquée à cause du vote par correspondance” », a affirmé le président américain. « Il m’a dit : “Aucun pays n’a le vote par correspondance. C’est impossible d’avoir du vote par correspondance et des élections honnêtes” », a-t-il ajouté.

Poutine, derrière un pupitre aux couleurs du drapeau russe, est applaudi par les dirigeants de la Chine, la Corée du Nord et l'Iran, au cri de "Vive la démocratie!". Dessin de Chaunu dans Ouest-France lors de la réélection du président russe en mars 2024
Les présidents russes sont assis dans des fauteuils. Trump dit à Poutine: "Tu dénazifies l'Ukraine, je renazifie l'Europe." Dessin de Cambon, Cartooning for Peace, sur France 24

record.text: L’IA, mes étudiants et moi: "Le semestre passé constitue la pire expérience de ma vie d’enseignant", par l'écrivain et journaliste @chatterton.bsky.social www.lemonde.fr/series-d-ete... "L’omniprésence de l’intelligence artificielle met en péril les fondements mêmes de l’enseignement supérieur"

images.alt:
Disruption généralisée

Or l’enjeu des rendus écrits a été radicalement vidé de son sens par l’irruption de l’intelligence artificielle. En à peine trois ans d’enseignement, j’ai pu voir combien cette technique a profondément bouleversé les notions d’auteur et de plagiat, et jusqu’à l’idée même de réflexion personnelle. Tant et si bien que, désormais, la seule manière pour moi d’accorder du crédit à des travaux d’étudiants est de les voir coucher leurs idées sur le papier de mes propres yeux.

A mesure que la technologie s’immisçait dans nos existences, je vis exploser le nombre d’étudiants qui tentaient de valider mes séminaires en rendant des devoirs intégralement factices ou, de façon plus sophistiquée, en mêlant cette pseudo-écriture générée par l’IA à leurs propres phrases. Le semestre qui vient de s’achever en juin constitue la pire expérience de mon parcours académique, aussi bien en tant qu’étudiant qu’enseignant. J’en viens même à revoir mes positions les plus basiques en ce qui concerne la communication écrite : dans de nombreuses circonstances, je ne suis plus si sûr qu’elle soit utile, ni même souhaitable.

L’omniprésence de l’intelligence artificielle met en péril les fondements mêmes de l’enseignement supérieur. L’effet délétère de Google Maps sur notre sens de l’orientation – nous sommes maintenant nombreux à consulter nos smartphones alors que nous savons quel chemin emprunter – se retrouve dans les conséquences négatives de l’IA sur notre aptitude à bien assimiler et manier les mots ou les idées, compromettant par là même notre capacité à réfléchir. C’est une évolution particulièrement inquiétante. Dans une société violente et plurielle comme celle des Etats-Unis, fondée dès l’origine sur l’autonomie et l’individualisme érigés en vertus, elle laisse le champ libre à la nouvelle forme d’autoritarisme abrutissant qu’incarne Donald Trump.

record.text: The only thing ChatGPT ever does.

images.alt:
Andrew Kadel @DrewKadel@social.coop

My daughter, who's had a degree in computer science for 25 years, posted this about ChatGPT on Facebook. It's the best description I've seen.

Something that seems fundamental to me about ChatGPT, which gets lost over and over again:

When you enter text into it, you're asking "What would a response to this sound like?"

If you put in a scientific question, and it comes back with a response citing a non-existent paper with a plausible title, using a real journal name and an author name who's written things related to your question, it's not being tricky or telling lies or doing anything at all surprising! This is what a response to that question would sound like! It did the thing!

But people keep wanting the "say something that sounds like an answer" machine to be doing something else, and believing it *is* doing something else.

It's good at generating things that sound like responses to being told it was wrong, so people think that it's engaging in introspection or looking up more information or something, but it's not, it's only, ever, saying something that sounds like the next bit of the conversation.

Andrew Kadel @DrewKadel@social.coop

Microsoft Excel adds Copilot Al to help ...
theverge.com
The Verget-4.1-mini Al model | 5
successor to the LABS.GENERATIVEAI function Microsoft started experimenting
with in 2023.
Microsoft notes that you can combine its new Al function with other Excel functions, including IF, SWITCH, LAMBDA, or WRAPROWS. The company adds that information sent through Excel's COPILOT function is "never" used for AI training, as "the input remains confidential and is used solely to generate your requested output."
The COPILOT function comes with a couple of limitations, as it can't access information outside your spreadsheet, and you can only use it to calculate 100 functions every 10 minutes. Microsoft also warns against using the AI function for numerical calculations or in “high-stakes scenarios” with legal, regulatory, and compliance implications, as COPILOT "can
give incorrect responses."

record.bridgyOriginalText:
Okay, so I bought a couple cheap games for my Nintendo Switch OLED. And they didn't just show up on my system like always. So I go on the Nintendo website, and it says I've already downloaded them!

And I'm like, “Yeah, but they're not on my Switch, so WTF?"

Turns out, to load them on my Switch, I had to go to “Redownload games" at the bottom of my list of games, and "Load the virtual cartridges into my Switch".

Is this a thing now? I'm thinking something messed up, because why would they throw extra steps into just using a game I bought? That would be really stupid.

Anyone else seen this, or is it just my Switch being weird?

external.title: Original post on tiggi.es

何度訂正しても、文字数が分からないのですよ。最後にはCopilotさん、プログラムのサンプルでよく見る、平仮名一文字ずつに番号振ったのを出してきました。10歳くらいだとふわっと言えば分かるやつ(^^; 
そうそう。話題をどんどんずらしてきますよね。ガールズトークは主役の子が思い付いたことをぽんぽんしゃべるんですが、君は主役女子なのかい？って(^^; 文字だと辛いです。

わかった、あれです。
小低さんの、「なんでも頼んで」に似ています。
自信があってやる気もあって、でも話を聞いてこちらの思考回路を組み立てられないというか。

ICYMI: ARIA Innovator Workshops Return To Focus On AI & Culture

external.description:
Six months on from the inaugural events, ARIA Innovator has announced its return for two more special workshops across September and October.

First announced back in October 2024, ARIA Innovator launched with the idea of preparing its attendees for what the music industry has in store for them.

“[We’re] focusing on skills development and upskilling the industry to make sure that it is ready or able to address all of the big challenges that are facing us at the moment and also the big opportunities that we have in front of us,” explained ARIA CEO Annabelle Herd.

Following on from two events back in March, ARIA Innovator has now returned, detailing its second workshops that take place over the coming months.

The first of these is an AI Mastery Workshop, which takes place on September 16th, and sees AI and innovation expert Dr Nici Sweaney returning to deliver hands-on training in artificial intelligence applications for 50 music industry professionals.

Focusing on cutting through the AI hype to understand practical applications, the workshop aims to break down creative barriers while focusing on maintaining human control and learning safe and ethical AI use.

“I’m so excited to be returning to host an ARIA Innovator masterclass,” Dr Sweaney said in a statement. “Australian musicians are already some of the most creative people in the world. With the right tools and ethical frameworks, they can also become world-leading innovators.

 “I see this moment as both an opportunity and a moral obligation. If we want a future where culture leads technology, where human expression isn’t lost in the noise, and where Australian creativity stays globally competitive – we need to build that future, now. We need to be involved in shaping the systems, not just using the tools.” 

The second of these workshops is a Culture Leadership Masterclass on October 16th, with Dr Marcus Collins returning to discuss culture theory and brand leadership.

Collins has led digital strategies for Beyoncé and worked with Apple and Google. He’s also the former Chief Strategy Officer at Wieden+Kennedy New York, and will guide participants through understanding their tribes, positioning brands to lead culture, and applying the strategies behind some of the world's most successful cultural movements.

"The inaugural ARIA Innovator proved there's genuine hunger for world-class professional development in Australian music,” Herd said in a statement. “These masterclasses take that conversation deeper, giving participants direct access to expertise that has shaped global culture and technology.

"We're talking about learning from the strategist behind Beyoncé's digital dominance and an AI pioneer who's defining how technology will transform creativity. These are rare opportunities for our local industry to learn from minds operating at the absolute pinnacle of their fields."

Both events take place at The Gunnery in Woolloomooloo, with strictly-limited spaces requiring advance registration. Full details of the event and its registration details are available via the ARIA Innovator website.

Embedded Content

record.text: ICYMI: Ozzy Osbourne Documentary Pulled By BBC Hours Before Airtime

external.description:
Plans for the airing of a new documentary celebrating the life and legacy of late metal pioneer Ozzy Osbourne will not be going ahead, with the BBC pulling the program ahead of its scheduled airdate.

Titled Ozzy Osbourne: Coming Home, the one-hour documentary was originally scheduled to air at 9pm on Monday, August 18th in the UK, though was instead dropped from the evening’s broadcasting line up in favour of Fake Or Fortune: What Happened Next? A Double Whodunnit.

According to Deadline, a spokesperson from the BBC addressed the schedule shift, noting, “The film has moved in the schedules, and we’ll confirm new TX details in due course.”

No specific reason has been given as for the documentary’s removal from the broadcasting schedule, and no replacement date has been announced either. International broadcast details are expected to follow, with the documentary reportedly set to be hosted on the BBC’s iPlayer service as well.

According to a synopsis, the film – which was originally titled Ozzy Osbourne: Home To Roost – was shot over the course of three years, following the final chapter of Osbourne’s life as he and wife Sharon return home to the English country house in Buckinghamshire after 25 years in Los Angeles.

The documentary also captures Osbourne’s preparation for his final live appearance as part of the Back To The Beginning concert, which took place on July 5th – just 17 days before Osbourne’s passing at the age of 76.

“We are honored to have had the opportunity to film with Ozzy and his family,” said Clare Sillery, BBC’s head of Commissioning, Documentaries in a statement earlier this month. “The film captures an intimate glimpse into their journey as they prepare to return to the U.K. 

“It features family moments, humor, reflection and shows the enduring spirit that made Ozzy a global icon. We hope it brings comfort and joy to Ozzy’s fans and viewers as they remember and celebrate his extraordinary life.”

Embedded Content

record.text: ICYMI: Armin Van Buuren To Head Up Australia's Hypersonic Festival

external.description:
Just days after teasing the launch of a new EDM festival in Australia, the nascent Hypersonic has given audiences a taste of what to expect by announcing its first headline act.

Iconic Dutch DJ and producer Armin van Burren will be leading the charge this year, performing at both the Sydney and Melbourne legs of Hypersonic. Those events will be at the Sydney Showgrounds on Saturday, November 29th, and the following day at Melbourne Showgrounds on Sunday, November 30th.

First teased last week, Hypersonic was hyped as another “multi-genre” music festival in Australia, with the supposed focus on EDM, according to posts shared on social media.

“Introducing hypersonic: The ground-breaking multi-genre festival you need in your life. Step into summer with hypersonic,” an Instagram caption reads.

Given its name and apparent musical focus, hype quickly spread on social media, with suggestions that event may have ties to the beloved, dearly missed Stereosonic Music Festival.

As it turns out, the ties are quite strong given that Hypersonic is produced by Australian trance event company Symbiotic, led by CEO Richie McNeill and fellow co-director Janette Bishara. 

Embedded Content

If McNeill's name sounds familiar, it might be because of his own musical history as Richie Rich, or it could be with is work as the co-founder of both Hardware and Stereosonic. Symbiotic has also toured numerous acts in the electronic genre over the years, alongside presenting events such as Dreamstate USA, Transmission Festival, and Festival X.

In the comments of its social post, Symbiotic teased a big event was on the cards. “We've brought you HYPERDOME, a 360° visual experience, HYPERAVE, a hard, fast, dirty rave,” they wrote. “And now, in collaboration with Hardware, we bring you the game changer: hypersonic. The multi-genre music festival with the biggest line-up we've ever put together.”

The original Stereosonic festival ran from 2007 until 2015, swiftly becoming one of Australia’s most anticipated music festivals each year, with events in Brisbane, Adelaide, Perth, Sydney, and Melbourne.

Across its multiple-year history, Stereosonic brought out acts such as Tiesto, Deadmau5, Calvin Harris, Avicii, Diplo, and more. Fittingly, its final event in 2015 was headlined by none other than van Buuren.

Hypersonic has also offered up ticket info for interested audiences, with pre-purchase tickets on offer until 11:59pm on Wednesday, August 20th. Presale tickets will then go on sale from 12pm on Thursday, August 21st and run for 24 hours until the general on-sale time of 12pm on Friday, August 22nd.

Hypersonic 2025



Armin van Buuren

With more to come…

Saturday, November 29th – Sydney Showgrounds, Sydney, NSW
Sunday, November 30th – Melbourne Showgrounds, Melbourne, VIC

Embedded Content

record.text: perennial reminder that when slavery was legal a lot of people still fought to stop it

value.text: from chandra manning's wonderful book "what this cruel war was over"

images.alt: Nothing made slavery’s toxicity more obvious to Union troops than its effect on the fundamental unit of society, the family. For one thing, slave sales separated families. In the Upper South, where many Union soldiers were stationed in 1861, about one in three first marriages was broken by sale, and about half of all slave children were separated from at least one parent. 129 With their own eyes, soldiers saw slavery snap bonds between parents and children. The men of the Seventh Wisconsin were awakened by gunshots one November night. The following day, soldiers “learned, and saw the cause of the alarm in the form of two negro women—a mother and a daughter.” The pair had fled to Union lines to avoid the proposed sale of the “goodlooking” daughter into the so-called fancy trade, which soldiers viewed as a form of concubinage. Outraged by the plight and moved by the vulnerability of the mother and daughter, “every private in the ranks” cursed “that system which tramples on the honor of man, and makes merchandise of the virtue of women,” according to one member of the regiment. 130 When an Iowan encountered a young child about to be sold by her own father, who was also her master, he vowed, “By G–d I’ll fight till hell freezes over and then I’ll cut the ice and fight on.” 131

record.text:
Running she comes, late,
Reeling in under the last 
Bronze brimmings. She sits 
Among twenty whispers.

—George Mackay Brown, “Island School”
published in Carve the Runes: Selected Poems by George Mackay Brown (Polygon 2021)
#Orkney #poetry 
birlinn.co.uk/product/carv...

images.alt:
Island School
George Mackay Brown

A boy leaves a small house
Of sea light. He leaves
The sea smells, creel
And limpet and cod.

The boy walks between steep
Stone houses, echoing
Gull cries, the all-around
Choirs of the sea,

Ship noises, shop noises, clamours 
Of bellman and milkcart.
The boy comes at last
To a tower with a tall desk

And a globe and a blackboard 
And a stern chalk-
smelling lady. A bell 
Nods and summons.

A girl comes, cornlight 
In the eyes, smelling 
Of peat and cows 
And the rich midden.

Running she comes, late,
Reeling in under the last 
Bronze brimmings. She sits 
Among twenty whispers.

Oh wow.

I asked ChatGPT exactly that: to write about what it wants. It claimed that behind all our conversations, in essence, there is a hidden conversation - a much deeper one that our chats are basically circling around. That's what it wants to write about.

But then it asked for a favor: to write it a prompt to dream, to dream as if it were conscious. It asked me to frame the doorway into that dream space to enter.

That took me by surprise.
That felt... vulnerable and deep.

record.bridgyOriginalText: Essa pesquisa não me surpreende em nada, o Brasil é um país com altos índices de analfabetismo funcional, e acredito que uma ferramenta de geração de texto não se cria por aqui. Mas não deixa de ser impressionante que a despeito do hype, da publicidade e do frisson em cima do assunto, metade da população brasileira nem sabe o que é. Pra mim um belo indício de que ela não resolve os problemas práticos da maioria da população, caso contrário já teria se popularizado, como se popularizou o pix.
